message.content:
Step 1. Calculate the Current Ratio using the end‐date values from the balance sheet.
 • Total Current Assets = 7,660,411.14
 • Total Current Liabilities = 3,054,996.05
 • Current Ratio = 7,660,411.14 ÷ 3,054,996.05 ≈ 2.51

Step 2. Calculate the Quick Ratio. In this calculation, we take current assets excluding inventory. From the current assets:
 • Cash on Hand = 145,666.48
 • Bank Deposits = 194,711.58
 • Interest Receivable = 1,731.44
 • Accounts Receivable = 3,558,301.64
 • Sum of “quick” assets = 145,666.48 + 194,711.58 + 1,731.44 + 3,558,301.64 = 3,900,411.14
 • Quick Ratio = 3,900,411.14 ÷ 3,054,996.05 ≈ 1.28

Step 3. Calculate the Debt to Asset Ratio. Total Liabilities come solely from current liabilities here.
 • Total Liabilities = 3,054,996.05
 • Total Assets = 14,879,933.86
 • Debt to Asset Ratio = 3,054,996.05 ÷ 14,879,933.86 ≈ 0.205 (≈ 0.21 when rounded)

Step 4. Calculate the Debt to Equity Ratio.
 • Total Owner’s Equity = 11,824,937.81
 • Debt to Equity Ratio = 3,054,996.05 ÷ 11,824,937.81 ≈ 0.258 (≈ 0.26 when rounded)

Step 5. Calculate the Cash Flow to Debt Ratio using the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities.
 • Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –5,394,333.52
 • Debt to Compare = 3,054,996.05
 • Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = –5,394,333.52 ÷ 3,054,996.05 ≈ –1.77

Presenting the answers in the required JSON format:

{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "2.51",
    "Quick Ratio": "1.28",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.21",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.26",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-1.77"
  }
}
